Code

Code

  filter(Conference == "Big Ten Conference")




Code
avg_plays_24 <- logs_big10_24 |> 
  group_by(Team) |> 
  summarise(avg_plays = mean(TotalPlays))




Code
avg_plays_25 <- logs_big10_25 |> 
  group_by(Team) |> 
  summarise(avg_plays = mean(TotalPlays))


To start, I used ggplot() with the 2025 dataset (avg_plays_25) to create a bar chart, mapping Team to the x-axis and avg_plays to the y-axis, then reordered the teams by average plays. I styled the chart with geom_col(fill = “red”), added axis labels, and used coord_flip() to make the teams readable along the vertical axis. I repeated the same process for the 2024 dataset (avg_plays_24), this time filling the bars blue to distinguish the seasons.


Code
ggplot(avg_plays_24, aes(x = reorder(Team, avg_plays), y = avg_plays)) + 
  geom_col(fill = "blue") + 
  scale_y_continuous(labels = comma) + 
  labs(
    title = "More plays don't equate to success, as seen by the 4-8 Terps", 
    x = "Team", 
    y = "Average Plays in 2024"
  ) + 
  theme_minimal() + 
  coord_flip()











Code
ggplot(avg_plays_25, aes(x = reorder(Team, avg_plays), y = avg_plays)) + 
  geom_col(fill = "red") + 
  scale_y_continuous(labels = comma) + 
  labs(
    title = "Maryland averages the fifth-most offensive plays with a freshman QB", 
    x = "Team", 
    y = "Average Plays in 2025"
  ) + 
  theme_minimal() + 
  coord_flip()









The 2025 chart shows Maryland averaging the fifth-most offensive plays, suggesting tempo has remained a key part of its strategy under a new quarterback. In contrast, the 2024 chart highlights that more offensive plays didn’t always translate to wins, as Maryland still finished 4–8 despite ranking high in tempo. Across the two years, the overall distribution indicates Big Ten teams are running slightly fewer plays on average in 2025 compared to 2024. A notable shift is that Rutgers and Indiana moved upward in the rankings this season, while teams like Purdue and Iowa have fallen further behind.
The biggest takeaway is that pace alone doesn’t guarantee success — it must be paired with efficiency and execution.

title: How Maryland Scores: Aces, blocks, kills and errors by the numbers
text:
I first had to load the tidyverse and waffle libraries so R could read the data, summarize it and create the waffle charts.

I next loaded the volleyball match data, filtered it for Maryland, calculated the team’s total stats and stored those totals in a simple named vector called md.


Code
maryland_data <- match_data |>
  filter(team == "Maryland")




Code
md <- maryland_data|>
  summarise(
    total_kills = sum(kills),

1         574         136.         73             298

)




Code
md


         Kills         Blocks           Aces OpponentErrors 
         574.0          135.5           73.0          298.0 


I created a waffle chart showing Maryland’s point breakdown, scaling the totals for display and using different colors for each category.


Code
waffle(md / 25,
       rows = 10,
       title = "Maryland's points",
       xlab = "1 square = 1 point",
       colors = c("red", "black", "yellow", "grey"))









I filtered the data for Wisconsin, calculated its total stats and saved those values in a named vector called wi.


Code
wisconsin_data <- match_data |>
  filter(team == "Wisconsin")




Code
wi_totals <- wisconsin_data |>
  summarise(
    total_kills = sum(kills),
    total_blocks = sum(block_solos + (block_assists / 2)),
    total_aces = sum(aces),
    opponent_errors = sum(defensive_errors)
  )




Code
wi_totals


# A tibble: 1 × 4
  total_kills total_blocks total_aces opponent_errors
        <dbl>        <dbl>      <dbl>           <dbl>
1         756          147         75             291




Code
wi <- c(
  Kills = 756,
  Blocks = 147,
  Aces = 75,
  OpponentErrors = 291
)


I combined Maryland’s and Wisconsin’s waffle charts side by side to compare their point distributions.


Code
iron(
  waffle(md / 25,
         rows = 10,
         title = "Maryland's points",
         xlab = "1 square = 1 point",
         colors = c("red", "black", "yellow", "grey")),
  waffle(wi / 25,
         rows = 10,
         title = "Wisconsin's points",
         xlab = "1 square = 1 point",
         colors = c("red", "black", "gray", "darkred"))
)









Maryland’s point distribution shows a more balanced mix across categories, with kills making up the largest share but a notable contribution from opponent errors as well. Wisconsin relies more heavily on kills and blocks, indicating a stronger offensive presence at the net. Maryland earns a greater portion of its points from serving and opponent mistakes, while Wisconsin’s totals suggest it creates more of its own scoring opportunities through attack efficiency and front-row play.

Code
library(cfbfastR)


I filtered the play-by-play data to include only 3rd-and-6 plays from the 2021–2025 seasons, then grouped them by play type to count how often each type occurred.
This shows which kinds of plays teams most commonly call in that specific down-and-distance situation.


Code
pbp <- load_cfb_pbp(seasons = 2021:2025)




Code
third_and_six <- pbp |>
  filter(down == 3, distance == 6)




Code
play_type_counts <- third_and_six |>
  group_by(play_type) |>
  summarize(count = n()) |>
  arrange(desc(count))




Code
play_type_counts


# A tibble: 23 × 2
   play_type                  count
   <chr>                      <int>
 1 Pass Reception              4985
 2 Pass Incompletion           3982

 5 Timeout                      967
 6 Sack                         817
 7 Passing Touchdown            523
 8 Interception Return          256
 9 Rushing Touchdown            146
10 Fumble Recovery (Opponent)    95

Most 3rd-and-6 plays are passing attempts, with nearly 5,000 pass completions and about 4,000 incompletions, compared to around 3,300 rushing plays.
That means teams across college football clearly prefer to throw the ball on 3rd-and-6, although a meaningful share still choose to run in that situation.


Code
run_summary <- third_and_six |>
  mutate(is_run = play_type == "Rush") |>
  summarize(
    total_plays = n(),
    total_runs = sum(is_run),
    pct_runs = (total_runs / total_plays) * 100,
    avg_yards_gained = mean(yards_gained)
  )

1       16447       3362     20.4             5.30


I calculated how often teams ran the ball on 3rd-and-6 plays and the average yards gained on those plays.
Teams ran the ball on about 20% of 3rd-and-6 plays, gaining an average of roughly 5.3 yards per rush, showing that while runs are less common, they can still be moderately effective.

I filtered for rushing plays on 3rd-and-6, grouped them by team and season, and counted how many times each team ran in that situation.Teams like Army and Navy led the nation in 3rd-and-6 rushing attempts, reflecting their strong reliance on run-heavy offensive systems.

md_third_and_six_runs <- third_and_six |>

I filtered for Maryland’s rushing plays on 3rd-and-6, grouped them by season, and counted how many times the team ran in that situation each year.
Maryland’s 3rd-and-6 rushing attempts have declined steadily since 2023, dropping from four runs that season to just two in 2024 and one so far in 2025.That pattern suggests that after Maryland’s Illinois loss in 2023 — when conservative play-calling was questioned — Mike Locksley has leaned even more toward passing in medium-yardage spots, trusting his quarterbacks over the run game on critical downs.

I filtered the data for Maryland’s 3rd-and-6 plays, grouped them by play type, and counted how many times each type occurred. Most of Maryland’s 3rd-and-6 plays were passes — with 27 completions and 18 incompletions compared to only 17 runs — showing that Mike Locksley heavily favors the passing game in medium-yardage situations.


Code
cfb_play_type_counts <- third_and_six |>
  filter(offense_play != "Maryland") |>
  group_by(play_type) |>
  summarize(count = n()) |>
  arrange(desc(count))

# ℹ 13 more rows




Code
library(waffle)


I wanted to see how Maryland’s play-calling on 3rd-and-6 compared to the rest of college football to understand whether Mike Locksley’s approach was more balanced or predictable in those crucial situations. By visualizing the run-pass split, I could see if Maryland leans more on its run game than most teams or follows the national trend of passing in medium-yardage downs.


Code
md <-c("Passing" = 25, "Rushing" = 17)
cfb <- c("Passing" = 8922, "Rushing" = 3345)

iron(
  waffle(md,
         rows = 10,
         title = "Maryland 3rd & 6 Play Types",
         xlab = "1 square = 1 play",
         colors = c("red", "black")
  ),
  waffle(cfb / 100, 
         rows = 10,
         title = "Rest of CFB 3rd & 6 Play Types",
         xlab = "1 square = 100 plays",
         colors = c("orange", "blue")
  )
)









This chart shows that Maryland runs the ball on 3rd-and-6 more often than most college teams, but still passes slightly more overall.
In the top waffle, Maryland’s passing and rushing squares are almost evenly split, while in the bottom waffle the rest of college football is overwhelmingly pass-heavy. That contrast suggests Maryland maintains a more balanced approach on 3rd-and-medium situations, while other programs tend to lean heavily on the passing game.

title: No rushing attack? Can you win with less than 100 rushing yards?

Code
library(lubridate)


Maryland’s offense hasn’t abandoned the run — it just hasn’t had much choice. The Terps have been forced to lean heavily on their passing game the past two seasons as rushing production has dipped, yet they’ve still managed to win some games despite the imbalance.
But that approach raises a question heading into this season: can Maryland keep winning that way? Across college football, teams that rush for under 100 yards rarely come out on top — especially in the SEC and Big Ten, where ground games still define success. Data suggests it’s a risky way to live.


Code
logs <- read_csv("footballlogs1525.csv")


Rows: 17133 Columns: 79
── Column specification ────────────────────────────────────────────────────────
Delimiter: ","
chr  (11): Location, Opponent, Result, OT, Bowl.x, TeamURL, Outcome, Bowl.y,...

lgl   (3): Score, TeamScore, OpponentScore
date  (1): Date

ℹ Use `spec()` to retrieve the full column specification for this data.
ℹ Specify the column types or set `show_col_types = FALSE` to quiet this message.


Code
logs <- logs |> 
  mutate(Season = case_when(
    month(Date) == 1 ~ year(Date) - 1,
    .default = year(Date)
    
))

season_games <- logs |>
  group_by(Season) |>
  summarise(all_games = n())


season_games_under_100_wins <-logs|>
  filter(Result == "W", RushYds < 100)|>
  group_by(Season)|>
 summarise(low_rush_wins = n())




Code
combined_games <- season_games |>
  inner_join(season_games_under_100_wins, join_by(Season))|>
  mutate(pct_low_rush_wins = low_rush_wins/all_games *100)

I filtered the dataset to only include Big Ten games, then calculated how many total games and how many wins with under 100 rushing yards occurred each season. After joining those summaries, I computed the percentage of games where the winning team rushed for under 100 yards.


Code
logs_bigten <- logs |>
  filter(Conference == "Big Ten Conference")




Code
b1g_season_games <- logs_bigten |>
  group_by(Season) |>
  summarise(all_games = n())


b1g_season_games_under_100_wins <-logs_bigten|>
  filter(Result == "W", RushYds < 100)|>
  group_by(Season)|>
 summarise(low_rush_wins = n())




Code
b1g_combined_games <- b1g_season_games |>
  inner_join(b1g_season_games_under_100_wins, join_by(Season))|>
  mutate(pct_low_rush_wins = low_rush_wins/all_games *100)


I filtered the dataset to focus on Maryland’s games, then calculated the total number of games and how many wins featured over 100 rushing yards each season. After joining those summaries, I found the percentage of wins with 100+ rushing yards. Finally, I created a dumbell chart comparing Maryland’s percentages (in red) to the rest of the Big Ten (in blue) across seasons.


Code
logs_maryland <- logs |>
  filter(Team == "Maryland")




Code
md_season_games <- logs_maryland |>
  group_by(Season) |>
  summarise(all_games = n())


md_season_games_under_100_wins <- logs_maryland |>
  filter(Result == "W", RushYds < 100) |>
  group_by(Season) |>
  summarise(low_rush_wins = n())


md_combined_games <- md_season_games |>
  inner_join(md_season_games_under_100_wins, by = "Season") |>
  mutate(pct_low_rush_wins = low_rush_wins / all_games * 100)




Code
ggplot() +
  geom_dumbbell(
    data = b1g_combined_games |>
      inner_join(md_combined_games, by = "Season", suffix = c("_BigTen", "_Maryland")),
    aes(
      y = as.factor(Season),
      x = pct_low_rush_wins_BigTen,
      xend = pct_low_rush_wins_Maryland
    ),
    size = 2,
    colour = "grey",     
    colour_x = "blue",   
    colour_xend = "red"  
  ) +
  labs(
    title = "Maryland has won more games with under 100 rushing yards\nin the past two years compared to the rest of the Big Ten",
    subtitle = "% of wins with under 100 rushing yards (Blue = Big Ten, Red = Maryland)",
    x = "% of Wins with <100 Rush Yards",
    y = "Season"
  )


Warning: Using the `size` aesthetic with geom_segment was deprecated in ggplot2 3.4.0.

This chart shows how Maryland stacks up against the rest of the Big Ten when it comes to winning without a strong rushing game. Over the past two years, the Terps have actually won more often than the conference average despite rushing for under 100 yards. It’s a sign that Maryland’s passing attack has carried them even when the ground game hasn’t clicked.

title: How much progress have the Terps had?
text:
Maryland football has spent the past decade straddling the line between progress and plateau. Recently, coach Michael Locksley has called earning a second conference win a success this season — which some called a low bar.
Outside of just win totals, has he shown much progress over his entire seven-year tenure?
A look at the Terps’ yards-per-play efficiency from 2015 through 2025 shows a program that has rarely separated from the national average — competitive enough to contend but not consistent enough to contend for titles.


Code

  mutate(wins = case_when(
    grepl("W", Outcome) ~ 1,

Code
ypp <- winlosslogs |>
  group_by(Season, Team, Conference) |>
  summarise(TotalPlays = sum(TotalPlays),
            TotalYards = sum(TotalYds),
            DefPlays = sum(DefTotalPlays),
            DefYards = sum(DefTotalYds),
            Wins = sum(wins)) |>
  mutate(
    OffensiveYPP = TotalYards / TotalPlays,
    DefensiveYPP = DefYards / DefPlays
)


`summarise()` has grouped output by 'Season', 'Team'. You can override using
the `.groups` argument.




Code
avg <- ypp |>
  group_by(Season) |>
  summarise(
    offense = mean(OffensiveYPP),
    defense = mean(DefensiveYPP)
)


Across the past decade, national averages for yards per play have stayed remarkably consistent.
Offenses across FBS hovered between 5.7 and 5.8 yards per play, while defenses allowed roughly 5.5 to 5.7 yards per play in most seasons. That stability means even small movements above or below averages can signal meaningful change. For Maryland, which often sits right around those benchmarks, breaking into the upper-right quadrant of the grid — meaning teams with both efficient offenses and stingy defenses — remains a challenge.


Code
all_teams <- ypp
umd <- ypp |> 
  filter(Team == "Maryland") |>
  mutate(incomplete = Season == 2025)




Code
ypp |> 
  ungroup() |> 
  summarise(
    offense = mean(OffensiveYPP), 
    defense = mean(DefensiveYPP)
  )


# A tibble: 1 × 2
  offense defense
    <dbl>   <dbl>
1    5.76    5.63


Across every FBS team from 2015 to 2025, the average offense produced about 5.76 yards per play, while the average defense allowed 5.63 yards per play.
Those numbers form the baseline for the grid lines in the visualization that follows. Teams above the horizontal line gave up fewer yards per play than average, while teams to the right of the vertical line moved the ball more efficiently.
For Maryland, that means seasons landing near the center of the chart represent years of average play on both sides of the ball — a decade defined more by balance than by breakthrough.


Code
ggplot() + 
  geom_point(
    data = all_teams, 
    aes(OffensiveYPP, DefensiveYPP, size = Wins), 
    color = "grey", alpha = 0.5
  ) + 
  geom_point(
    data = umd |> filter(Season != 2025),
    aes(OffensiveYPP, DefensiveYPP, size = Wins),
    color = "red"
  ) +
  geom_point(
    data = umd |> filter(Season == 2025),
    aes(OffensiveYPP, DefensiveYPP, size = Wins),
    shape = 21, fill = NA, color = "red", stroke = 1.2
  ) +
  geom_vline(xintercept = 5.762959) + 
  geom_hline(yintercept = 5.627613) +
  geom_text_repel(
    data = umd, 
    aes(OffensiveYPP, DefensiveYPP, label = Season), size = 3
  ) +
  labs(
    title = "The Terps’ offense and defense show mixed results across the past decade.",
    subtitle = "The Terps rarely break into the upper tier of efficiency on either side of the ball.",
    caption = "Source: NCAA"
  ) +
  theme_minimal() +
  theme(
    plot.title = element_text(size = 16, face = "bold"),
    axis.title = element_text(size = 8),
    plot.subtitle = element_text(size = 10),
    panel.grid.minor = element_blank()
  )









Maryland’s placement on the YPP grid shows a decade defined by balance but inconsistency.
Most of the Terps’ red dots cluster near the center, meaning their offensive and defensive efficiency has hovered around the national average since 2015. A few seasons, such as in 2021 and 2019, stand out slightly because of stronger offensive output. Others, like the 2022 and 2023 seasons, are lower as defensive lapses cancel out modest offensive gains.
Across the 10-year span, Maryland never breaks into the lower-right or upper-left quadrants, which would represent dominance on one side of the ball for the Terps.
Instead, the program consistently lands in the middle — competitive but not elite, which aligns with the narratives around most of Coach Michael Locksley’s seasons. The incomplete 2025 season, shown as an open circle, continues the trend so far, with early numbers again mirroring the national baseline.
In fact, both defensive and offense metrics have progessed slightly less.
So should two wins over mediocre average opponents this season be considered a success?

title: NFL Redzone EPA Reverse Engineering
text:
Few stats reveal a team’s growth like red-zone efficiency — and this season’s shifts tell a clear story.
The Colts have emerged as the defining example, turning an already explosive offense into the league’s most efficient unit near the goal line. Detroit and Denver have climbed right behind them, converting drives at an elite clip, while the Giants and Houston continue to stall out when it matters most. Even Baltimore, steady elsewhere, hasn’t shown much red-zone progress — a trend likely tied to Lamar Jackson’s extended absence.

The Colts are the standout story. Now 7-2, they’ve taken one of the league’s top overall offenses and made it even more efficient in the red zone. Their green point sits far to the right of their blue one, showing significant positive movement.
Detroit and Denver have also trended upward, continuing to convert drives into touchdowns at an elite rate. On the flip side, the Giants and Houston remain among the worst at finishing possessions, showing little to no improvement.
Baltimore has also suprisingly not shown much improvement — which could be factored with Lamar Jackson missing about half the season thus far.
